header_summary:
A novel approach within the Quantum-Resistant Address Migration Protocol (QRAMP) suggests transitioning legacy Unspent Transaction Outputs (UTXOs) to a "quarantine mode," enabling post-quantum spendability through a two-phase commit-and-spend process, which includes a mechanism for fee sponsorship to ease user experience challenges. This method aims to safeguard against destination substitution by necessitating a commitment phase before any spend, addressing significant technical hurdles in consensus enforcement without reliance on historical transaction indexes. Further details and visual aids for this mechanism are available for review at [Markdown](https://github.com/bnavf/bitcoinqp/blob/main/two_phase_destination_commitment.md) and [Diagram](https://github.com/bnavf/bitcoinqp/blob/main/two_phase_destination_commitment.svg).

In parallel, Bitcoin Core's latest version, v30.2, introduces enhancements and bug fixes to improve performance, compatibility, and user interface, urging the community to report any issues via their [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues). This update, tested across multiple operating systems, marks a significant step in the software's evolution, underscoring the contributions of numerous developers and translators. Detailed information about the release and upgrade instructions can be found on [Bitcoin Core's website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.2/).

A recent scholarly paper published on arXiv offers a geometric framework to analyze phenomena within payment channel networks like the Lightning Network, proposing a novel throughput law and advocating for the structural efficiency of multi-party channels over traditional two-party ones. This research, complemented by practical discussions on liquidity management and fee strategies, aims to enhance network sustainability and payment feasibility, with supporting materials available at [arXiv](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2601.04835) and [DelvingBitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/ark-as-a-channel-factory-compressed-liquidity-management-for-improved-payment-feasibility/2179).

Lastly, the integration of Nostr notifications within the Silent Payments protocol represents a forward leap in digital transaction communication, aiming to foster a more responsive and interactive user experience. This development, part of a broader trend towards integrating financial technology with communication platforms, invites community engagement and contribution on [DelvingBitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/silent-payments-notifications-via-nostr/2203), promising to redefine user expectations in digital finance.

recent_posts.title: QRAMP addition: Alternative to legacy freeze: “quarantine-mode” legacy spends via two-phase destination commitment
recent_posts.summary:
- QRAMP introduces a two-phase commit and spend flow for UTXOs in quarantine mode.
- This approach ensures spendability post-quantum, requiring on-chain commitments and matching proofs.
- It proposes fee sponsorship for the commit phase, seeking feedback on similar mechanisms and technical feasibility.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v30.2 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v30.2 has been released, featuring new updates and bug fixes.
- Upgrade guidelines emphasize complete shutdown of older versions before installing v30.2.
- Significant changes include wallet migration fixes and improvements in build and documentation.

recent_posts.title: A Mathematical Theory of Payment Channel Networks
recent_posts.summary:
- A new paper analyzes critical phenomena in payment channel networks, focusing on the Lightning Network.
- It introduces a throughput law and discusses payment feasibility, channel depletion, and multi-party channel efficiency.
- The paper also explores practical strategies for liquidity management and encourages community engagement and further research.

recent_posts.title: Silent Payments notifications via Nostr
recent_posts.summary:
- Bob faces challenges verifying tweak data in blockchain transactions, requiring accuracy.
- Two strategies discussed: minimizing message data and enhancing DoS resistance.
- Decision-makers must weigh simplicity against security in transaction management strategies.

recent_posts.title: Stealth addresses using nostr
recent_posts.summary:
- The integration of notifications with Silent Payments via Nostr enhances digital transactions.
- A specification is proposed to use Nostr for interactive transaction notifications in digital currency.
- Interested individuals can contribute to its development on DelvingBitcoin's dedicated discussion page.

active_posts.title: Addressing remaining points on BIP 54
active_posts.summary:
- Luke Dashjr criticizes BIP 54 for compromising ASIC optimization by embedding extranonce in nLockTime.
- Jeremy Rubin proposes a sparse Merkle tree over size restrictions to avoid smart contract complexities.
- The consensus prefers solutions that avoid major protocol changes, focusing on stability and pragmatism.

active_posts.title: Follow-up regarding Motion to Activate BIP 3
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin community broadly supports adopting BIP 3 following positive feedback and key endorsements.
- Concerns led to modifications of BIP 3, which were well-received after reversing the LLM-policy.
- Broad community and key figure support suggests a move towards consensus on activating BIP 3, despite calls for wider evaluation.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v30.2rc1 Released
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v30.2rc1 has been announced with new features and bug fixes.
- Users should entirely shut down older versions before upgrading to ensure a smooth transition.
- The update offers backward compatibility and supports Linux Kernel 3.17+, macOS 13+, and Windows 10+.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The analysis suggests improvements for Bitcoin's protocol, including fixing the timewarp vulnerability.
- It proposes limiting non-SegWit transactions and invalidating small transactions to improve security.
- While some solutions like reducing block size are debated, the focus remains on enhancing integrity and efficiency.

active_posts.title: A simple backup scheme for wallet accounts
active_posts.summary:
- Josh's method includes unique inscription and location attributes.
- The proposal suggests standardizing Salvatore's method before adding Josh's unique aspects.
- Combining both methods could create a comprehensive solution with standardized processes and innovation.

active_posts.title: What is the importance of running a node?
active_posts.summary:
- The debate focuses on the personal security benefits of running a node.
- Critics question the practical advantages, noting a lack of clear incentives.
- The gap between theoretical benefits and practical accessibility hinders widespread adoption.

today_in_history_posts.title: Proof-of-Stake Bitcoin Sidechains
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Matt Bell developed a Bitcoin sidechain design using the Tendermint BFT consensus protocol.
- His design resembles Blockstream's Liquid sidechain in its "strong federation" consensus mechanism.
- Matt seeks feedback to refine his design, sharing a detailed document and implementation link.

today_in_history_posts.title: Lightning and the semantic web
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Melvin aims to integrate the Lightning Network with Solid by creating an ontology.
- He seeks existing work in this area and collaboration on ontology creation.
- Solid enables user data control, while Lightning Network enhances Bitcoin transactions.

today_in_history_posts.title: Emulating OP_RAND
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The proposed method allows for emulating randomness in Bitcoin transactions without protocol updates.
- It employs a trustless interactive game, ensuring fairness and security without external observation.
- Demonstrated through a Thimbles Game, it introduces secure, random outcomes within Bitcoin's limitations.
